div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: IN HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S CONSULAR COURT AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: NOTICE
JOHN THOMAS BURTON
decreases

PURSUANT to Act of Parliament 22 and 23 Vict o 35, intituled “An Act to farther amend the Law of Property and to relieve Trustees,” NOTICE is hereby given that all creditors and persona having any claims or demands upon or against the estate of JOHN THOMAS BURTON late of Ramleh Alexandria decreased (who died on or about the 12th day of September 1905, and whose will was proved by Lucy Helen Booth Burton of Ramleh aforesaid spinster and John Habbalday Barton of Alexandria Coal Merchant one of the Exeuatrices and the Executor therein named, on the 5th day of October 1905 in bis Britannio Majesty’s Consular Court at Alexandria) are hereby re- quired to send in particulars of their claims and demands to the undersigned, the Advocato of the said Executrix and Executor, on or before the 14th day of November proximo : AND NOTICE is hereby also given that after that day the said Executrix and Executor will proceed to distribute the assets of the decreased among the parties entitled thereto, having regard only to the claims of which the said Executrix and Executor shall then have notice, and that they will not be liable for the suets or any part thereof so distributed to any per- son of whose debt or cloim they shall not then have had notice.
Dated this 20th day of October 1995.
Frederick Leveaux,
9, rue Debbane, Alexandria.
Solicitor of the Supreme Court in England.
Avocat pres la Cour Mixte.
BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE

British Chamber or Commerce.—We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appoint- ing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of £1. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber, Home enquirers can obtain further particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: BIRTH
div.p: HOPKINS
On the 19th inst. at the Anglo-American Hospital, Cairo, the wife of James F.G. Hopkins, of a daughter

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established 1850
Editor and Manager : R. SNELLING
Price: One Plastre Tariff
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1905
THE "ARAB AWAKENING"

Sometime ago we recieved a copy of M Neguib Azoury's interesting and suggestive work, "Le Reveil de la Nation Arabe," an elo quent plea for the revival of an Arab Caliphastic extedning from the Yemen to Aleppo and from Oman to the hills of Kurdistan. We have no fault to find with M. Axoury's essay as a propagandist appeal to certain Arabic speaking peoples, but in out opinion the "Arab Nation” of which the author speak with such fire and eloquence does not exist And those who count on the spiritual an mental development of Arabia as a factor in the politics of the Near East will be grievoual disappointed. All who have followed the history of the peninsula since the beginning the Wahabi "revival" realise that, thus fa every movement among the Arab clans ha been reactionary and conservative. Wha ever the religions zeal of the Wahal leaders, their whole policy was so bigoted and savage, that the capture of Dereyeeyah Ibrahim Pasha proved a relief not only Arabia, but to the whole Moslem world The present Emir of Hail, Abdul Aziz Hashid, who resembles his famous uncle Mohamed ibn Rashid, the Bedounin lord the Nejd, has paid for his dynasty's tolerable of strangers and freedom from religion bigotry by losing the greater part of his ter- tories to the Wahabi chiefs of the house Sa’ud. From all accounts the present of the Yemen, who is apparently eager to co- ntinue a guerilla warfare in the arid mountains of Arabia “Felix," is in no way in advance his neighbours. The very fact that the Turb faed by terrible geographical and climate difficulties, and hampered by their own la of organization, have been able to established their authority over the whole western seaboat of Arabia and, if the latest reports are accurate over a part Of the Nejd, proves the capacity of the pare Arabs for any sort political union. The Caliphates of Baghdad, the Arab kingdoms of N. Africa, Syria, and Egypt were founded by Arabs and ruled monarchs of more or less Arab descence but their peoples were never Arab as whole, though they were modified by Ai elements. The “Arab" of modern Egypt largely mixed with Coptic blood, and the sical difference between a pore-bred' dew Arab end a fellah is almost as great aa that tween an Abyssinian and a Circassian. Arab speakers of Syria, Barbary, and Irak in the majority of cases Arabised Syria Kabylee, or Chaldeans, and when we hear the Arab awakening we should like to know what section of the "Arab" peoples it applies Syria and Egypt have progressed, Arabia mains in the tribal stage, and that pure like a true son of the desert, prefers his independence to Empire-building. His infuence has been kinetic rather than construction. His independence and strength of character have enabled him to rule over less vigor races, end to impact some of his own to them, but the very excess of these excel- lent qualities keeps Arabia hundreds of years behind the rest of the Moslem world. when tribe neutralises tribe the way is for the persistant Turk, who has at least, of political construction, and certainly stands that Empire-building is impossed without the subordination of the individualism.
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.

div.head: WARNING TO VENEZUELA
MR. ROOSEVELT AND THE NEIGHBOURING STATES.
div.p: New York, October 19.

President Roosevelt is making a tour of the Southern States. Speaking at Richmond, he said that it is possible to give the neighbour- ing States of Central and South America a wire as well as generous assistance. If the country refuse such assistance, it will be so much the worse for these nations, and for the United States, who will probably at last be ebliged to face either their humiliation or a scene of bloodshed.
This is a direct warning to Venezuela and Saint Domingo. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIA AND JAPAN.
TSAR'S PEACE PROCLAMATION.
div.p: St. Petersburg, October 19.

In proclaiming peace to Tsar refers to the gallantry of the troops in the struggle against a brave and mighty enemy. He prays that the blessings of Providence may rest on the Im- peril labors, in co-operation with the efforts of the people's representative, for the pros- purity of Russia. (Reuter)
St. PETERSBURG, October 19.
An Imperial manifesto announces that peace has been concluded and adds that the eastern portion of Russia may develop its relations with Japan, who has now become a friend. (Havas)

div.head: NAVAL REVIEW AT TOKIO
IMPOSING ARRAY OF SHIPS
div.p: Tokto, October 19.
A naval review will take place in Tokio Bay on the 23rd instant. The ships will be arranged in 7 columns extending 10 miles, the captured vessels heading the line. (Reuter)

div.head: RANSOM OF BRITISH OFFICERS
VALIENTE LIBERATED.
div.p: MADRID, October 19.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has tele- graphed to the Spanish Minister at Tangier to obtain the liberation of the brigand Valiente, whose brother holds the British officers as hostages. (Reuter)
TANGIER, October 19.
A Moorish Government steamer is expected at Ceuta to-night, bringing the brigand Va- liente as ransom for the British officers. (R.)

div.head: THE KINGDOM OF NORWAY.
PRINCE CHARLES APPOINTMENT.
div.p: CHRISTIANIA, October 19.
The negotiations regarding the appointment of Prince Charles of Denmark as King of Norway are still proceeding through the crown has not yet been formally offered to him. (R.)

div.head: THE ROYAL TOUR.
DEPARTURE OF THE PRINCE.
div.p: LONDON, October 19.
The Prince and Princess of Wales have started for India. (Reuter)

div.head: PRINCE FERDINAND
div.p: PARIS, October 19.
The Prince of Bulgaria has left for Creusot. (Havas)

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY FOOTBALL.
div.p: A football club has been started in con- neutron with the Scotch School, and there is every evidence that it will be a great success. The colors are those of the school, blue and white with a tartan sash, to pronounce their association with the land of the canny ones. The teams will practice every day, and matches will be played on Saturday afternoon. Mem- bers and friends are invited to attend and cheer on this enterprising school in its athletic endeavors, besides seeing an invigorating exhibition of the manly game as taught by an English master. Challenges are invited from other teams, any strength. Address, Mr. Maurice Goodrick, Scotch School, Alexandria.

div.head: "TROTTER EGYPTIEN"
div.p: The trotting races which were to have been held on the 5th, 12th, and 19th November have been postponed till the 19th and 26th November and 3rd December. Entries will close on Thursday, 9th November.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: THE BRINDISI MAIL will close at the G.P.O, Alexandira, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.
THE PLAGUE- Yesterday's plague bulletin is a clean short for the whole of Egypt. Only one case now remains under treatment.
Suez Canal- 184 vessels passed through the Canal from the 6th to the 16th inst., the dues from which amounted to frs. 4,968,298.51.
STRAY Dogs.- Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Esbekieh quarter of Cairo during the night of Saturday will be poisoned by the police.
ARMY OF Occupation- A board of officers assemble in the office of the G.O.C. in Egypt, at 10.30 a.m. to-day, to consider the estimates of the Command for the financial year.
MAN OVERWHELMED- A native, names Ahmed El Sayid, who was digging in a pit of sand at Karmous, was overwhelmed by a land- slip and buried alive. The unfortunate man was asphyxiated.
The MAIEH SANIEH- The personnel of the Maieh Sanieh will leave for Cairo on Sunday. Preperations are already being made at Mohar- rem Bey stations for the approaching departure of the Khedive.
CAPTURE OF SHARK- Yesterday morning, two boatmen caught a shark, 7 feet long, in Port Said harbour. The monster was safely landed, and was subsequently visited by hun- dreds of people.

ANARCHIST ARRESTED- Vittorio Jaffei, an Italian Anarchist banished from Egypt for threats against H.H. the Khedive, was recently arrested at Marseilles at the instance of the Italian consular authorities.

WORKMEN ENTOMBED- Seven workmen of Mahallat Abi-Ali were working on a building at Senhoor when a wall gave way and fell upon them. Two of the workmen were killed outright and the others seriously inured.

TRAM ACCIDENT- A Syrian woman named Victoria Tagiad, aged 30, who endeavored to step down from a tramcar before it stopped near the Menthe yesterday, fell and was run over. The woman received very serious injuries to both her feet, and was taken to hospital.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Their Excellencies the Ministers came down to Alexandria from the Capital last night in order to accompany H.H. the Khedive to Mansourab.
During his stay at Alexandria, H.E. the Sirdar made a call upon H.E. Ghari Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner in Egypt.
News comes from Paris to the effect that H.B. the Maronite Patriarch left for Constan- tonople on the 11th inst, after the receipt of a telegram from the Sultan inviting him to the Turkish Capital.
Thurneyssen Pasha is staying at the Grand Hotel Frohner, Vienna and will not return to Egypt for some time.

The post of first secretary to the French Di- plomatic Agency at Cairo, left vacant by the transfer of M. Lacomte to Belin, has been filled by the appointment of M. Panatieu, first secretary at Tokyo.
Major E.J. Lawsom, Senior Veterinary Offi- ver in Egypt, came down to Alexandria from Cairo yesterday on duty connected with his department.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place on the 23rd inst., at Buxton, Derbyshire, between Captain C.E. Bowen, Burma Commision, and Norsh May, second daughter of Mr. Frederic Guy and Mrs. Guy, of Port-Said.
The Hon. Sidney Carr Glynn has contribut- ed $5 to the funds of the Rudolph Home, Alexandria, in memory of his son, the late Mr. George Carr Glynn.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Echange Hotel, Port Said, are Sir Malcolm Mcllwraith, Capt. and Mrs. Lyons, Mr. G. Mavro, Mr. T. Hug, Mr. G.F. Felso, Mr. N. A. Moscow, Mr. A. G. Griffin, Mr. Smyth, Mr. Gredy, Mrs. Page and child, Mr. P. R. Boxwell, Mr. A. St. John Diamant, Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Murray, Hassen Bey Ride, Miss L.C. Barney, Mr. H. J. de Joug, Schonwenburg, Mr. J.J. Van Noort, Mr. J. H. Spillenaar and Mr. G. Ripert.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES
THE EXPERTS SECOND REPORT
div.p: At 3.15 p.m. yesterday the experts second report on the situation of the Sucreries Com- many was read to a large and interested au- dience. The three experts, Sir William Will- cocks, Fourneron Bey, and M. Sampaolo, were present, as were Harari Pasha, the Hon. A. J. Davey, M. Naus, and many well-known legal and financial personalities. Judge Tuck opened the sitting and the clerk of the court, M. Zigliara, read the lengthy report of the experts for the next hour.

We have not the space to give our readers the full text of this long and important document. Suffice to say that the experts criticize the administration of the company in revere terms and have much to say concern- ing the conduct of previous auditors of the company's accounts. On the other hand, the Hon. A. J. Davey escapes from the cen- sure of the experts, which weighs only too heavily on some of the directors, thanks to the publication of correspondence ex- changed between him and M. Cronier which proves that he entirely disagreed with the section of his colleagues.

This correspondence consists of two docu- ments, vz:- 1. A telegram from Pouliguen dates August 12, 1905, which runs as follows: "Honc- table Davey, Caire. Eu raison circonstan- ces commerciales difficiles vous prie laisser Ninci la plus grande indépendance pour direction services a lui confies sous sa res- ponsabilite et la mienne; Amities- CRONIER."
Translation: - Owing to commercial difficulties beg you allow Ninci utmost freedom of action carry our services confided to him under his responisibility and mine; Regards, CRONIER
2. The Hon A. J. Davey's reply (translated) to the above is as follows:- "Cairo, August 16 1905.

Dear M. Cronier, - I have received your wire and forward you a copy thereof under the same cover. I have not replied by wire, preferring to explain to you by letter the features of a situation which has become impossible for me in consequence of the underhand proceedings at my expense, that have continued too long. The actual point of difference is on the question of my rights of control and authority, in my capacity as the only administrator- delegate present here, and not on the question of the inde- pendence allowed to M. Ninci in his conduct of our commercial affairs, for I have never in any way impeded the carrying out of the services confided to M. Ninci and defy any one to prove the contrary. Concealment of the truth is not my way of doing business, and as fat as services towards the successful prosecution of our business are concerned I have done as much as others who appear to have more to show. The future will prove my statement.

Here are the facts. One day last week I asked to see and sign the letters containing orders. I made a point of keeping myself well informed about the business of this bureau, whether all the orders were properly transmitted to Paris, whether directors of the factories did not demand impossible amounts, the price of purchases, - in a word, I carried out quietly and conscientiously the functions which are mine by right as administrator- delegate, and I did my best to do my duty.

M. Ninci was vexed, and promptly proceed- ed to telegraph, I have no notion why. In short, when I called upon him to explain his attitude, he replied- and I beg you to note his reply- that he was the representative of M. de la Bouglise during my colleague's absence, and that in consequences he was my equal, and that I had no right to give him any orders whatever, or ask whether he was at Alexandria, or Cairo, or elsewhere. Leaving the personal attitude of M. Nincy out of the question I ask you in all frank- ness whether that is the way for him to behave towards me; If you approve his attitude,- which I refuse to believe- what is my position here.

Now, as for the question of my irrespond- disability for M. Ninci's proceedings, allow me to say that maybe all very well between out- selves, but that to the shareholders, the public, and the Government authorities I remain -and I am - administrator delegate, and whatever my confidence in M. Ninci, I cannot admit that I have no right of control over our employee, or that any inferior can deny my authority, however indirectly. In your own case you ought to know well enough that at your distance you cannot have all the means of control desirable to enable you to take upon yourself the responsibility for akk M. Ninci's acts. Finally, if I accepted this situation, I should simply become a man of straw with a title and a name that would be lent to our business and a complete ignorance of its nature. I may remind you that Lord Dufferin made a similar mistake, and I decline to accept such a situation. You must also be aware of the con- stant difficulties that have appeared among our board. I consider that our business cannot co-exist with these internal dis sessions. On that account I can say that, were I to retire, my retirement might profit the company, the board, and the committee of director. Therefore, if under the circumstances you disapprove of my views as to my right of control and authority as the only administrator-delegate present here. I have to inform you that I cannot continue my functions. If you disagree with my views I should not propose to leave you suddenly, but should look our for some other position in Egypt, where I intend to stay permanently.

Before I close, I ought to tell you, to give you full information about the incident, that M. Naua, on being questioned by me before M. Ninci, loyally and absolutely recognized my rights of control, and my authority based on my position of administrator- delegate. M. Naus has done his best to persuade M. Ninci to accept our point of view, and as M. Ninci refuses to yield I am obliged to forward you this ex- planation. I am keeping M. Leroux in- formed as to the situation and beg you to accept the assurance of my sincere personal friendship.- ARTHUR J. DAVEY

The reading of the report was followed by a brief speech from Me. Carton de Wiart, who remarked that the experts seemed not to have touched at all on certain interesting points, Judge Tuck here interposing that the Sucre- rise Company's shareholders and creditors were also interesting enough. Maltre Carton de Wiart the proceeded to say that in the inte- resta both of the company and the shareholders their present expectant attitude could not be indefinitely maintained, and that a period of four weeks would be necessary for the experts to complete their task. The documents read had been most interesting, but the company had to find out whether the business should be carried on, and in four weeks they would be ready to give an immediate answer on the receipt of the final report of the experts. The final report will therefore be submitted to the Court and read on Thursday, Novem- ber 16.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive left Montazah early this morning for Mansoureh, and was met at Sidi Gaber by H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy and the Ministers and the Governor of Alexandria, who accompanied his Highness to Mansourah. The Municipal Commission of Mansourah gave a banquet 100 covers in honor for the Khedive, who was expected to open the agricultural show at 2p.m to-day.

The Khedive leaves for Cairo on the 26th inst. the special train leaving the Bab-el-Ghedid station at 7.20 am and stopping at Daman- hour, Tantah, Birket-el-Sab, and Benha, and arriving at Cairo at 11.30 a.m. H.H. the Khedivah leaves on Montazah at 7.40 a.m. the same day by special train, only stopping at Damanhour and Tantah, and reaching Koubbeh Palace at 12.10 p.m.

div.head: THE PRINCES AND THE DAIRA
div.p: The appeal lodged by the Princess, heirs of the late Khedive Ismail pasha, against the decision of the Cairo Mixed Court contains the following interesting passages:-

"Attenda que c'est a tort que le juge des referes, retenant as competence a, sur la de- mande du gouvernement, autorise la Societe Egyptienue de la Dora Sanieh a se liberer valablement entre les laine du gouvernement sans tenir compte des exploits notices les 10 et 21 colt 1905 par les princesses et princess heritiers du Khedive Lsmail;

"Attenda que c'est a tort que le juge des referez considère les défenses faites daus ces exploits comme des saisies-arrêts, qui auraient été pratiquées d'une façon irrégulière; "Attenda qu'en l'espèce il ne s'agit nulle ment de saisie-arrêt mais d'une reclamation directe entre les mayas de la Daira Sanieh des sommes provenant de la liquidationn des biens Daira;

"Attenda qu'i net certain que le juge del referes en autorissant en l'espece la Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh a se liberer va- blessent entre les maine de l'Eat a implicite- ment préjuge une question de fond qui happait a sa competence.

"Par ces motifs et tons autres dont est reserve expresse, ententre dira la present ap- pel recevable et fonde, et la Cour, y faisant droit, entendre infirmer et mettre a néant l'or- donneuse du 12 octobre 1905 dont appel; entendre dire et juger que le juge des referez était incompétent a statuer sur la demande introduite par le gouvernement egyptian sui- can't exploit de l'huisseier Pugnaletto end'edo 9 octobre 1903. S'entendre tous les intimes con- jointement et solidairement condamner ans Frais de lire instance et d’appel. Sous tontes Reserveres de fait et de droit.”

div.head: MINISTRY OF FINANCE
div.p: Mr. McKillop, inspector in the Ministry of Finance, has returned from leave and resumed His duties, and the districts of inspection are In consequence modified as follows;- Mr. McKillop is charged with the inspection of the Moudiriehs of Menoufieh and Fayoum; Mr. Henz, of Dakahlieh and Kalioubieh; and Mohamed Effendi Moussa of Mine and Assiout.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The new Moss liner Menepthah sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is expected Here on Sunday evening or Monday morning With passengers, mails and general cargo.
The Khedival Mail S.S. Ismalia will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Pireous, Smyrne, Mitylene and Constantinople.
The Elerman S.S City of Cambridge sailed To-day at daybreak for Liverpool direct with General cargo, including 5,749 bales cotton.

div.head: NEW MAIL ROUTE.
BERLIN IN 4 1/2 DAYS.
div.p: The Vienna correspondent of the “Financial News” says that the Austrian Lloyd is now Threatened with serious competition in its Levant and Egyptian lines, which hitherto Have been reckoned amongst the best-paying Services of Austria’s principal navigation con- cern. It is announced that, with the co- Operation of the North German Lloyd, an Arrangement has been arrived at for the crea- Ion of an express service between Central Europe and Egypt, via Roumania, whereby the Journey from Berlin to Alexandria would not take more than four and a half days at the outmost.

From October, 1906, the Roumanian mail Steamer service running between Constantza, Constantinople, Smyrna, and the Pireus will Be extended to Egypt. The new service will be Organized under the auspices of the Romanian Government by the North German Lloyd, and Would have, as a result, the quickest conec- Ion between Central Europe and the Far East, Particularly Australia, via Port Said. Fears are Being expressed in Austrian shipping circles Lest the bulk of European postal and passenger Traffic to Egypt would be forfeited by Trieste, And, consequently, for Austria.

div.head: MINING IN EGYPT.
EGYPTIAN MINES EXPLORATION.
div.p: Mr. C.J. Alford has furnished the following Summary of the month’s operations: Atalia Mine- (Central Egypt Company)- September 23rd- Main Shaft down 116 feet. No. 1 Shaft, 2nd Level N.E, 90ft vein disturbed, 9dwts gold per ton. 1st. Level N.E, at 33 ft Holed into cross out from No. 2 Shaft 1st Level S.W. and excellent ventilation thus provided. Stringer of quarts ent in crosscut assays 1 oz 4 dwts gold per ton.

Semna Mine- (Fatira Company)- Septem Ber 26th- No. 1 Shaft, 75 ft Level E, 64 ft, last 11 feet of vein averaged 12 ft wide 1 oz 9 Dwts gold per ton. No. 2 Shaft, 50 ft Level E, In old workings, pillar at 45 ft shows vein 60 Inches wide 2 oz 16 dwts; at 60 ft 35 inches, 13 Dwts per ton, No. 3 Shaft struck vein at 108 Feet, proceeding down on it to relative level of No. 1 Shaft on reaching which drives E and W Will be commenced. B. Vein cross out in 56 feet.
ERIDIA MINE- (Eridia Company) Work now Being recommended.

SUAKIN MINING SYNDICATE.- It was an- Bounced at the meeting of the Suaking Mining Syndicate, Limited, on Tuesday week that the Original concession had been abandoned as Worthless, and that a more promising one had Been obtained.

Um RUS GOLD MINES OF EGYPT- Cablegram From the mine, giving the return for Septem- Ber:- “610 tons of are were crushed; 444 czs. Of bar gold were produced, valued at $1,541. 488 tons of tailings have been stored, of an average assay value of 3 dwts. Per ton. The Mill ran 19 days of 24 hours.” August, 350 oz.

Nile Valley- Cable from the mine man- Ager, dated Allaghi, October 7:- “5 heads of stamps, running 16 days, yielded 222 tons in addition to 219 oz. from 150 lbs. specimens.” (Office note.- The latter part of this cable, referring to the 210 oz, has already been reported.

div.head: EGYPTIAN RELICS IN PALESTINE
div.p: The quarterly statement of the Palestine Exploration Fund contains a very interesting Account of some discoveries at Gezer during Excavations now terminated by lapse of the Firman. Mr Stewart Macalister has found a Connected series of artificial caves, which Obviously have been used as burial places. Most Of them have been plundered at an early date, Probably about 600 B.C., and by workmen who Broke into them when excavating cisterns in The limestone rock. Here and there, however, A few things escaped their notice, and one Deposit was untouched. Besides pottery, Mr. Mcollister found some beats, one or two objects in ivory, a few gold ornaments, and Several soarabe, sometimes is gold or silver amounts. These were of various materials, and All belong to the Middle Egyptian Empire, or About 2500 B.C., an approximate date which Accords with the pottery. In the floor of one Chamber are numerous cup-marks, of unusually Large size, and arranged in rude oval patterns. This rock-hewn cemetery was probably closed More than four thousand years ago, and I first Disclosed by the oyster-sinkers some fifteen Centuries later. This throws light on a fact which Hitherto has perplexed the explorers. In the Upper debris at Greger, Middle Empire scarabs Are rather unusually abundant, mixed with Late Assyrian remains. The plunder of these Tombs would “let loose a flood of scarabs” Over the city, and bring about this inter- Picture of ancient Egyptian with the modern Assyrian. Remains of importance have been Found in other parts of Gezer, including two Tombs, constructed of masonry, and contain- Ing skeletons in an extended position, the Date of which is probably about 1000B.C. (in One was an iron knite). But the rock-out Cemetery has a special interest, by proving a Close intercourse between Egypt and Palestine During the Middle Empire, and indirectly, as Mr, Macalister shows, by adding to the proba- bility that the early date for King Naram-Sin asserted by Nabonaid of Assyria was correct.

div.head: SUDAN RAILWAYS
SUAKIN TO ATBARA DAILY (FROM OUT CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: Suakin, October 14.

Kaimakam Drury Bey, R.N., Controller of Sudan Ports, left for Suez by the Khedivial mail steamer Dakahlieh on the 11th inst. On business connected with the new Budget and the regulations for the Sudan Ports Adminis- tration, which may probably be separated from the Sudan Railways at the end of this year. Drury Bey will be absent about three weeks. Kaimakam Longfield Bey, R.E, Acting Director of Railways, went to Railhead yester- day, taking with him a special material train, which will be the first to go through to Others. The train also takes a turntable, which will be put down at Athara. To-day Longfield Bey will meet Midwinter Bey at the two Railheads, and the last rail will be put down to join both ends. Thus the long-expected work will be completed. Time-tables are now being made here, and from the 16th inst. Trains will run Daily from Suakin to Athara, the run occupy- ing about 80 hours. A slow rate of speed will have to be maintained until the bridges are completed.

The German steamer Weissenfels arrived here from England on the 12th inst. With about 13,000 bags of cement for the Sudan Government Railways, Suakin-Atbara line. The railway people here have already start- ed pulling down iron sheds, which are to be transferred to the Athara.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: Suez, Thursday.

H.M.’s cruiser For arrived at Suez from Aden yesterday evening, and is not moored in the North Basin at Port Ibrahim for coaling purposes. She has come here in order to be in readiness to escort. H.M.S. Renown, with the Prince and Princess of Wales, the Bombay. This year’s pilgrimage has already begun. Up to date over 1,300 Asiatic pilgrims have embarked at Sea for Jeddah.
The Auchor linear Numbia, which was ashore at Ras Souhait in the Gold of Suez, entered the Khedivial Mail Line’s dry-dock for repairs this forenoon.

div.head: BEGINNER’S TERRIBLE DEATH (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: Port Said, Thursday

Mr. Mavros, second engineer of the new bucket dredger Ptolmene has met with a hor- rible end. He was engaged in making some repairs in the engine-room on Tuesday night, When it was found that there was defect in The crank pit. Mr. Mavros, after enjoining upotr his subordinate on no account to move the engines, started to remedy to defect. A few Moments after the bridge telegraph rang “Slow ahead,” and the young engineer, without thinking or looking to see whether Mr. Mavros had left the crank pit or not, set the engines in motion, with the result that, in less time than it takes to say it, Mr. Mavroe was crushed and mangled beyond recognition. His remains were brought ashore in a sack, and were buried yesterday afternoon. Mr. Mavros, who was a Greek leaves a widow and four children.

div.head: CORRESPONDANCE
div.p: LA COMMISSION DES LOCATAIRES
M. le Directeur de 1’ “Egyptian Uaistte"

Arec votre oourtoisio habituelle, je vont serais trèa obligé, de bien'vouloir mo perraottrr, an nom de la Commission Internationale dot Locatairea de répondre une fois pour toute' anx stupides élucubrations anonymes et anx malvoillantea insinuations qui voua aont adres- sées depnia quelque temps contre la dite Com- mission par un certain A. G. J’ai trop d'estime pour votre journal, pour entamer, dans ses colonnes, une polémiqua avec nn individu puisant sa force dans l'anony- mat et qui par ses absurdités, se révéle sinon comme un déséquilibré, dU moins commE un parfait ignare.

J’ai trop d'estime pour votre journal, pour entamer, dans ses colonnes, une polémiqua avec un individu puisant sa force dans l'anony- mat et qui par ses absurdités, se révéle sinon comme un déséquilibré, dU moins commE un parfait ignare.

C'est donc poor le public, et pour le public seul que je désire répondre an nom de tous mes collègues de la Commission. Loin d’etre tombée, cotte Commission — épurée do certains éléments nuisibles qui s’é- taient glissés dans sein et rencuvelée aprèi l'épuration en question — est aujourd'hui plus forte et plus résolue que jamais.

Depuis sa fondation, et malgré tontes les basses machinations qui ont été onrdies pour la faire, avorter, la Commission ne s'est jamais laissée décourager par qui et par quoi que ca soit et, à'juste titre, elle peut être Gère du travail accompli.

Elle a travaillé silencieusoment, o’est vrai 1 mais elle avi^t de graves raisons pour agir ainsi ; et, lorsque, bientot, il loi sera permis do rendre compte des bons résultats obtenu, non seulement elle confondra ses détracteurs, mais elle prouvera à ses mendants qu’elle n’a jamais cessé un seûl instant d'être digne do leur confiance.

Devant tant d’énergio et tant de ténacité, les autorités ont fini pV s'émouvoir et nous promettre de .s'intéresser è la cause si haute- ment humanitaire que nous nous sommes juré de défendre jusqu'au bout
Il est des secrets qui ne m'appartiennent point; mais sans me départure de la réserve qui m'est imposée, je puis, cependant, déclarer hautement que nous rommos désormais, tout près du but

Cotte déclaration pourra peut-être déplaire è quelques-uns, mais je suis certain qu'elle eau sera une légitime satisfaction aux nombreux philanthropes qui s'intéressent h la solution d’an aussi grave problème humanitaire. Et ils sont légion dans ce pays !
J. Mignot.
Membro de la Commission
Internationale des Locataires.
CURONIQUE THEATRALE
Edipe Roi

Si par la perfection da son jeu, le naturel de sa diction, l’incarnation complète de son per- sonnage un acteur peut faire courir un tel frisson d’enthousiasme parmi une assistance clairsemée que le théâtre semble plein, tant sont vifs et nombreux les applaudissements, on pent dire d'un tel acteur qu'il est hors pair. Cost actuellement lo cas du chev. Salvini. |i Après s'être montré l’Otello idéal, il a été an Edipe Roi saisissant de vérité et de convictioœ Las antres acteura ont d'ailleurs bien tenu leurs rôles respectifs. M. Diaz a été particuliè rement remarquable dans les rôles de Tirésias et de berger, ainsi que M. Olivieri dans celui de Créonte ; Mme Aliprandi a également été fort bien dans le rôle de Jocaste.
Eu aomnfe, la représentation a été excellent-' dans l'ensemble et le succes a été tel que l'émi- nent acteur a été frénétiquement applaudi et rappelé à diverses reprises.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: (From our Financial Correspondent).
London, October 13.
Tho Dominating Factor.

If you will tell me what is going to be the future of the Money market, then I am prepared to give a forecast of the prices of stocks and shares in tho immediate future. This is tho reply one has received throughout the week from most of tho leading financiers whom discussing the movements of stocks and shares. It would seem for the moment that the money market entirely dominates the situation, even the Delcassé exposure and the animosity which is being displayed by the German Press has had practically no effect on Stock Exchange values, as the incident is not looked upon in so serious a light as some of the less responsible newspapers would have us believe.
The Bank Reserve.

Whilst no alteration was made in tho Bank rate yesterday, still in Lombard-street discount is rates remained firm — the result, no doubt, of the poor showing of tho Bank return. There was a considerable enquiry for gold for Paris, but as no transactions took place no prices is transpired. The Bank reserve now amounts to only £10,586,000, which is a decline of nearly in £400,000. since our last. Over £500,000 of gold is expected to reach the Bank to-morrow. On tho other hand, £1,000,000 of gold whioh was shipped on account of the Indian paper currency reserve is, we learn, to be landed in Egypt, which will mean a similar amount of depletion to the Bank of England’s stock.
Consols.

Consols have been a more or less weak market in consequence of the money situation during the past week. They close to-day at 88 3/4. The bungling of the sale of a large block of lndian Threes, due to tho difficulties of to a firm of jobbers in the American market, and also the fact that a well-known firm of brokers were reported to be under the necessity of liquidating on a heavy scale to meet the differ- ences of clients, brought the price of these down from 96 3/8 to 95 1/8. This had its effect on other similar securities,, which were dull all yesterday, but leave off with a slightly better tone to day.
Foreign Markets.

In the foreign market, Russian bonds have given way somewhat and arc 1/2 down since our last report. They close to-day at 93 1/2 Japanese stocks have been sailing on a fairly even keel all the week, and show practically no difference in price. They are quoted tonight at 100 1/2. A fair demand has put up the prim of Egyptian Unifieds at least 1/2. There seems to be a good deal of attention given to the Egyptian market generally at the present time. National and Agricultural Bank shares show little change from our last and leave off at 27 1/2 and 9 3/4 respectively.
Say Reconstruction.

It will interest your readers to know what happened on Tuesday at the meeting of the shareholders of the Say Refinery Company. The result of this meeting was that, although at one time the 1,200 shareholders showed a good deal of dissatisfaction at the ignorance displayed on the directors as to the transaction! of M. Cronisr, still in the end they almost unanimously voted for the directors' proposa! for reconstruction. The scheme of reorganisation they agreed upon was as follows. The capital at present 32,250,000 francs, in 76,500 shares of francs each, is to be reduced to 15,300,0001 by making tho nominal amount of each of the present shares 200/. instead of 500f Fresh capital is to be obtained by the issue of 114,750 new 200f. shares, which will bring the total capital up to tho original amount. The new shares will bo issued at a premium of 40f. 30f. of which will be played te the reserve and lOf. set aside for the expanses and guarantee ing of the issue. Tho shares will be payable immediately, and will be entitled to partake it the profits from October 1st.

Although several of the shareholders would have liked to have had a tall discussion on the to acts of the late mauaging director, this was thought inadvisable at the present time, and was adjourned until the general meeting, which is to take place in November next.
Ralls.

In Home rails, prices ware more or lose affected by tho dullness of Consols, and con sequently, not with stannding the favorable trade advices and traffic of the last week, they leave off lower than they would otherwise have done. The American market is still in a waiting attitude, and is no doubt affected by the con- servative report of Mr. Vauderlip, of the Na- tional City Bank, who advises caution. Grand Tranks did not respond to the favorable state- ment as to prospecte at the meeting of the company yesterday, and Canadian Pacifics were 1 3/6 lower on the week at 176 3/6.
Mining Market.

In the mining market prices hâve escillât ed during the week, and there is very little to report concerning them. Rhodesian heure interested in tho Bankets have kept these steady at round about £5. The Egyptian section has managed to shake itself clear o the weight of Africans, and there was a distinctly better tendency throughout. The satisfactory statement made by Mr. Alford a the Central Egypt meeting yesterday bene- ficialiy affected tho whole of this market. Egyptian mines advanced to 15s. 9d. and were at one time almost 16s. Od., due to the very satisfactory news of the development in the Semna mine. Mr. Alford reports with reference to this mine that for 11 feet of driving on the 75 feet level from the No. 1 shaft the reef averaged 12 feet and assay 29 dwts. to the ton. In No. 3 shaft assay of 35 and 36 dwts. wire obtained over a width of 3 ft. Nib Valleys remain un- changed since last we wrote and are quoted Today at 1 3/14 United Africans have been A firm market, owing, it is said, to some good business which they bare done in the South African market.

div.head: SAY REFINERY CO
div.p: SCHEME OF REORGANISATION ADOPTED.

The extraordinary meeting of the sharehold- ers of the above com par y held in Paris on the 10th inst. (of which a brief account has already appeared in the "Gazette") was presid- Ed over by M. Peytel, and there was a very large attendance.

Tho chairman, in opening the proceedings, “We have called yon together today to lay before yon tho unfortnate position of this company, brought about by the deplorable act of tho late Provident, who died on the 27th of August last under conditions of which yon are aware. Let me recall, first of all. in what man- ner the management of this company was organised. Our object is entirely an industrial one. Oor business in Paris was to buy sugar, to refine it aud sell it at the highest price to the home trade. The surplus production we export'd. In the provinces our business was to buy beetroot, extract tho sugar from the kiot- root in the six factories which you possess, and to sell the beetroot to the highest bidder. No doubt the purchase of beet and the purchase and sale of sugar necessitate numerous and intricate commericial operations. There are sugar stocks to be obtained at the right mo- ment, but the risks should not degenerate into market speculations. Jour directors would never have sanctioned * ch speculations, and until a recent dite they supposed that the negotiations had been conducted in an orthodox manner."
At this point there were load and noisy interruptions, and shoots of "Yon knew all about it!"

"Gentlemen, please allow mo to proceed r appeaered the Chairman. ‘ When the late M. Henri Say became ill, and personal considera- tious determined him to sell his refinery in Paris and the sugar works at Pont d'Ardres, it was felt that this important business could only be properly carried on by those who had been for long years connected with the founder, M. Henri Say, in the conduct of the concern. Them were M. Cronier, ex chief Government Engineer of Roads and Bridges, also M. P6 lissier. who had charge for twenty years past of the technical department, M. Tellerman, the commercial manager, M. Letort, the adminis- trator, and M. Leroux. All bad been connected from fifteen to twenty years with the business. We paid these men limited salaries, but gave them a large share in the profits of the busi- ness. We would remind you that M. Henri Say and Company did not transfer to this com- pany all the r business, but continued to work on their own account tho .Egyptian Refinery and Sugar Works and the Electro Sugar Works, and MM. Cronier and Teller- man continued in an occasional way to lend Messrs Henri 8ay the benefit of their ex- perience.

div.head: TUB COMPANY'S CAREER.
div.p: "Now, gentlemen, yon know the result of the first six years of our existence. It, in brief enabled us to realise the sum of £1,255,800 in net profit, after payment of all expenses and Shares to the management. We find, however, from a rapid investigation of the books that of this sum we shall have to write off £73,600 from the profits for 1904 in consequence of surdry illicit manipulations of figures in the books. Wo shall also be obliged to place £413,960 in a sinking fund.

"The seventh year's business, which began on the 1st of October, 1904, promised to be excellent. The sugar campaign bad been very good and left net profits amounting to £156,000 In April last tbs fall in the price of sugar was outlined, bit we did not expect the fall to seriously interfere with the net profits already acquired. At most, the consequence of the fall in sugar might have decreased our profits during the last half-year. According to the information supplied to us by our manage- ment, we bad bought our sugar at a reason- able price, and these purchases were practically covered by the sales which we bad made in anticipation. Not only so, but a large portion of the sugar for 1905 was sold in advance. The general condition of the stocks and the fall in prices did not lead tie to expect any very considerable margin in prices. Such was the position as it was represented to year Said by the management, when suddenly, like a thundar-clap, the news of M. Cromer's suicide came.

div.head: M. CRONIER’S IRREGULARITIES.
div.p: "We have already pointed out that MM. Henri Say and Co. had continued to work side bv side with us with M. Say as the ma- aver. When M. Say died our general manager, M. Cronier, who had been previously appointed by the chief partners of the firm to be the ad minister and liquidator of Messers Henri Say and Co., took over the conduct of the business while still continuing to be our general manager. The credit of the firm of Henri Say and Co. took over the conduct of the and uncontested until the raws of M. Cronier’s suicide It was well knows that the fins po» w»sed most valrable assets and there was no reason to believe that these IM been gander ed. Indeed, M. Crontier's own personality, his reputation for ability, contributed to maintain the credit of the firm; and I need only point to the fact that the leading Paris banks made no difficulty within the last few months in discounting dose upon a million sterling of bills signed by M. Cronier as liquidator Messrs. Henri S»y and Co. This in itself will prove to you that even the great Pails bankers were convinced of the solvency of Masers. Henri Bay and Co.

"It was on Sunday, the 97th of August, that we heard of tbs suicide of M. Cronier. At first your directors were coder the impression that be has commited his rash act in consequenoe of personal embarrassments, but we did not then suppose that there would ultimately turn out to be a veritable disaster. On the following Tuesday, after a most anxious investigation into the book*, your Board awoke to the gravity of the position. In fact we discovered that the company was deeply compromised as a result of M. Cronier's business methods. He had made heavy purchases in Prance and still p heavier purchases . abroad in the name of the company, thus making us liable. He bad also given the company's gnarar.tr o to back certain. bills which he issued as liquidator of Messrs. Henri 8ay and Co. He bad also got our bankers to advance to Messrs. Henri Say and Co. without our knowing anything about the matter, a sum of no less than £880,000. I assert, gentle- men, that these facts were absolutely unknown to your Board."
There were loud protests at there words, and r cries of "It is impossible that that Board could have remained ignorant of such important matters”

div.head: THE RECONSTRUCTION SCHEME.
div.p: Amidst interruaptions and counter-interrup- tions from the twelves hundred shareholders present, the Chairman went on to explain at great length the circumstance connected with M. Cronier's malversations, from which it appeared that he had improperly converted to other uses a sum of £1,010,000, being the f moneys of. the company. The events which had taken place since the suicide of M. Cronier were then passed review. Ultimately, the Board of Directors submitted the following resolutions to the meeting : —

(1)That the capital of the company, which is now 32,2S0,000 francs, in 76,500 shares of 500 francs each, be reduced to 15,300,000 francs by writing down the nominal value of each share from 500 francs to 200 francs, and that each share be stamped with a stamp indi- caring this reduction. This resolution, however, not to become effective until the subscription to the preference shares which it is proposed to issue shall have taken plsoe, and only after the general meeting shall have taken cognizance of this subscription and of the consequent increase in capital.

(2)That the capital of the company be recon- structed and brought up to its original and present amount of 38,250,00} francs by an increase of 22,950,000 francs by means of an issue of 114,750 new shares of 200 francs each, which shall enjoy a right of preference as regards profits and also as regards assets in the event of liquidation. These preference shares are to be issued with a premium of 40 francs, of which 30 francs shall be carried to reserve and 10 francs shall be contributed towards the expensess and the guarantee of the Dew issue. These shares are to rank for profit from the 1st of this month, existing shafehol ders to have a prior right of subscription to . those preference shares.
After a long discussion the majority of this Shareholders voted far the proposals of the Board.

div.head: AN ANDREE MEMORIAL.
div.p: Up to the present teore has been no me- morial to commemorate Andree and his un- fortunate expedition. The Geographical Society of Stockhelm, however, has taken the matter in hand, and has commissioned Londberg, the Swedish engraver, to make a large memorial medal. The artist represents Andre’s balloon rising from the ice. The explorer is looking anxiously towards the North. A group of young men are applauding, while an old man looks , towards the horizon doubtfully. Below is the , date July 11, 1897. On the obverse appears the profile of Andree, with his name and the names of his companions, Sternberg and Fraenkel.

div.head: THE CANAL FROM THE CASPIAN TO THE PERSIAN GULF
div.p: Particulars of the German scheme for a canal to unite the Caspian Sea with the Per- Sian Gulf are furnished by the Paris “Eclair.” It is intended, of course, to counterbalance the British plan prepared by Sir William Willoocks, whose idea is to render the Tigris navigable as far as Diarbekir, where it would meet a railway line from Smyrna. The German plan, elaborated by Herr Waechtor, is to join Baghdad, the highest point of naviga- bility of the Tigris, to Buzali on the Caspian Sea, by connecting the Djioalla, a tributary of the Tigris, with the Kisil Usen, a river flowing into the Caspian. To do this it will be necessary to construct a vast reservoir in the mountains -dividing the two river basins, in order to provide water for the Kisil Ueen, which is generally dried np daring the summer. It is, of course, upoo the feasibility of this reservoir, which would have to attain the proportions of one of the greet 8wi*s lakes, that the realisation of the scheme depends. If deemed likely of success, Boteli would be connected with the Russian railway yatem in Persia by a line running to Hamadan.

div.head: A ROMANCE OF EMPIRE
div.p: THE LESSON OF THE UGANDA RAILWAY.

At lint light it would appear that the days of romance in connection with the Uganda Railway are ended. Not so many years ago we were entertained by stories (officially guaran- teed aa true) of elephants clearing out the hooking office* and of lion* carrying away pas- sangers from the carriages. Bees stung to death one unfortunate black, and careless giraffes knocked down the telegraph wires with 'hair unconcionably long necks. This last difficulty ha* been obviated by raising the wires to seventeen feet aboveground.

The latest report, just issued as a White Paper, is of a totally different character. It is a mass of figures, with the elaborate tables of mileage ran, cost of working,'average tonnage, and. other matters which repel all but the rail- way expert or anxious shareholder. Yet if this average Briton could be indeed to study the document—and the Uganda Railway is a national asset in which all taxpayers are shareholders—he would find in it the tree romance ; the wonder of a railway piercing to the heart of Africa and built across deserts, forests, and mountains whose existence was scarcely dreamt of in the youth of men not yet old, proving at once an economic success.

div.head: TUB NOW LAND OF PROMISE
div.p: As sandwiched between the mass of figures presented are acme very pertinent observations by there quiet men who serve Britain so well in the outposts of empire, it may not be super- fluous to emphasise the points which an attentive study of the return makes clear. The year 1904-5 is the first year of full and uninterrupted traffic on the 584 miles of rails which link Mombasa to the Victoria Nyanza. When the year began it was estimated that there would be a deficit on the twelve months’ working of '£15,000 (the railway, it must be remembered was built for political reasons, and as a groat blow to the slave trade, not on financial grounds, but the gross earnings, £141,000, greatly exceeded the amount an- ticipated, with the result that the expected deficit of £45,O0O was tamed into an actual net profit of £i,600. This was due to two causes : the rash of settlers and the rapid development of the staple product of the country. Over a thou and white men came to the new land of promise, and it is gratifying to learn that all the sound traders and tanners speak in high praise of the potentialities of the country. Already some 3,000 tons of good and handled monthly. The country produce,-ground nuts, fibres, hides, ivory, beans, potatoes, chilies, etc.— comes largely from Uganda that is, it is brought to the lake termenately steamer. So far, only the. districts close to the lake ports are tapped, ‘but this railway even now com- mands the trade of the German part of the Nyanza, and has alto attracted goods from the Congo Free State. There is no possible doubt as to the sound "divided" earning power of the railway, and its officials are keenly alive to the wisdom of satisfying the requirements of their customers in every legitimate way. Rates compare not unfavorably with those ruling in South Africa to me it the needs of settlers, and branch lines are contemplated.

div.head: BRITISH STEAMSHIP LINE WANTED.
div.p: There is, however, a reverse side to the pic- ture, forcibly portrayed by Mr. A. E. Crack- shank, the traffic manager. The railway is prospering, and likely to prosper still more, but the laisser faire of British statesmen is pre- venting England from reaping the full advan- tage of that circumstance. At present almost all the produce brought down by the railway, as well as the heavy goods brought to it, are carried to and from Mombasa in foreign bot- toms. This important and expensive railway— the taxpayers have spent over £5,300,000 on it —built entirely by Great Britain, is feeding French and German (chiefly German) steam- ship lines. Surely it is time, as recommended by Mr. Evelyn Cecil’s committee, that a sub- sidised British line be started. This is precisely one,of the occasions when to leave a job half done is the worst of follies. A line of British steamers which would serve all the ports in South-Bast Africa would regain much of the Zanxibar and Mombasa trade now in the hands of foreign nations. Given favorable shipping facilities and rates, the development of British Bast Africa and Uganda would be much more rapid than it can otherwise be. The building of the Uganda railway has proved “sane Imperialism" if anything ever has ; it is no evidence of sanity to withhold the subsidiary steamship service.

div.head: CONGO REGIME.
div.p: IS COLLAPSE IMMINENT

It is stated, with some degree of authority, Says the “"Daily News," that a state of affairs mounting almost to panio at present exists n the gorernment of the Belgian Congo. S0 lente, it is said, has the position Income that ; here is every possibility of the regime collapa- Ing altogether, when, it is suggested, Belgium should assume possession of the Free State. The population cf the State is rapidly dwindl- ing, sonsequent upon the conditions under Which the Administrations” is worked. The Rev. John H. Harris, attached to the Balolo Mission, on the Upper Congo, is now in London, fresh from the scenes of the horrible traffic in human flesh that marks the Free State. Mr. Harris, with a devoted band of 30-workers, has for the past seven years been working in the centre of the Abir district, where, perhaps, the worst of the terrible atrocities have been perpetrated.

"There is no question about it," said Mr. Harris to a representative of ‘The Daily News” recently, “that the one solution to this fearful state of affairs is an international conference ; until such is called nothing can be done. Diplomatic negotiations are absolute- ly of no avail. Take a case in point Lord Lasdowne was specifically promised by the Commission that all witnesses would be tho- roughly protected. As a matter of fact, various witnessses have been chased, captured. and transported to other districts, and that by a man against whom the most fiendish outrages were alleged.

"Again, in spite cf Lord Lansdowne's pro- tests, the mission centres are boycotted by the natives, at the instigation of the concession- naires. The natives have been threatened with the direct punishment if they dare bring us food, either flesh meat or vegetables; as a result we have, at great expense, to import tinned foods in large quantities, because we have no means of obtaining other.

"Would Belgium take over the Free State No, I don't think so. In the first place, I don't think it has any desire to. When offered it in 190 , it refuted, and asked that the matter should be postponed for ten years. Then again, it must not be forgotten that England would never consent to such a step. We had treaty rights on the Congo long before it became a Prei State, and these would not be willingly handed over. Another thing is absolutely cer- tain, England cannot and will not have the pre'eot regime carried on by the Government of another country."

The honorary secretary of the Congo Reform Association assures our contemporary in a telegram that the information given above is absolutely correct The Congo State, he adds, is undoubtedly evacuating all the smaller posts in the Stanley Pool district, while posts in the Kwango and Cataract districts, together with those at Lokolela, Yambu, and Kwamout, are being similarly dealt with. Most of them are lower Congo posts, and the motive is ostensibly economy, coupled with shortage of personnel.

div.head: GRECO-ROUMANIAN CONFLICT.
div.p: The following view of the right nationality to be given to the Kutiovlaohs of Macedonia is of interest, as coming from one of them- selves, and not from either Greek or Rouma- nian efficial sources. He says :— "The truth is that the majority of the Kutnvlaohs in Macedonia reckon themselves Greeks, and repel the suggestion ofbelonging to the Roumanians. Most of the Greek bands fighting against the Bulgarians in the south are made op of Kutsovlaohs. In the mountain villages our shepperds speak besides Greek the Aromanian dialect, especially the women. But if they need to write they most use the Greek characters. Bat we, who live in the towns have forgotten the dislect.

"In Monaatir.out of 8,600 Kuttovltoh-Greek families, only 31 have joined the Roumanian propaganda, and so it is in other towos. The fistitions character of the Roumanian agita- tation is best shown by the Committee. M. Douma was born a Greek, Now he is head of the Roumanian Propaganda, with 80 Turkish pounds a month. His lientenant is M. Set- drono, an Albanian, who was educated at the expense of Bulgaria, and then turned bis back on her, to take up the agitation in Macedonia for the pay of £12 a week from Roumania.”

div.head: WHERE CUPID SCORES.
div.p: A Board of Trade report shows that the comen of the United Kingdom have nearly twice as many chances of being married as have their alters in other European countries. In the ten years from 1898 to 1903 the mar- risge rate in the United Kingdom was from fourtoen to sixteen per thousand, while in the rest of Europe the rate was between reran and eight per thousand. The birth and death rates are shown to be decreasing generally. In spite of the fewer births, the population of; the United State* has increased by 11,488,000 in eight years (mostly by immigration), .and that of the United Kingdom in the same period by 1,160,000.
